title: Developper's websites are easily accessibles leading to massive information disclosure

profile.name: Maximum
profile.about: Maximum is a full-service agency specialised in employer branding and recruitment advertising.

vulnerability_information:
**Domain and URL:**
[*.devmaximum.com]
[███████████.acc.devmaximum.com]

Hello,

I've found a couple hundred of devmaximum websites with personal datas. 

I know this subdomains are out of scope, i've discovered them with [devmaximum.maximum.nl]'s SSL certificate. But in less than 30 minutes of testing i've discovered 116 uniques ███.ln emails addresses, here is a sample:
████████

Maximum's developers are using admin:admin as main password to access the websites.

## Impact

There are many impacts possible, attackers can use this massive email record (there are ██████
active users according to the statistics) to forge user:password combinaisons, and login in in █████████.nl website.

And that's only the first developper's website, i have 344 record only with Sublist3r (subdomain enumeration tool).

So I have a question, do you want me to keep digging into this, or should I stop my tests ? If you want me to dig in further, can you please add the devmaximum.com domain in the scope ?

Thanks,

Best regards,

Sicarius.

activities.message:
Ow, a very good find. It seems Basic Auth didn't check anything at all. So any username + password would have worked.

I've disabled https://███████████████████.acc.devmaximum.com/ and https://█████████████.acc.devmaximum.com/ (although this one doesn't show any confidential data)

devmaximum.com was our previous staging domain and only legacy applications are currently hosted on that domain.
Feel free to check for any other devmaximum.com sites as I've added it to the scope.

I'll check the logs for any illegitimate access and discuss with my colleagues the bounty amount

summaries.content: The authentication of an staging environment wasn't working properly, allowing any combination of username and password to access the environment. Causing the leakage of a emailaddress-list.
